Description: Pupil of an eye in transparent colourless moulded glass imitating crystal. Obverse convex, reverse slightly concave, with the edge bevelled; one side is slightly sharpened, the other rounded; probably from a statue, possibly of a cat.
Curator's comments: The Museum register does not specify any precise provenance, but the context of the list may infer a Tell Dafana origine and the item correspond most certainly with the "cover of an eye, hemispherical, probably from a cat's head, brilliantly cut in rock-crystal, with the corners of the eye produced", mentioned by W.M.F. Petrie, Tanis ii, Nebesheh and Defenneh, p. 73 § 70.
Bibliographic references: Petrie 1888 / Tanis. Part II. Nebesheh (Am) and Defenneh (Tahpanhes) (p. 73 § 70) (?)
Leclère and Spencer 2014 / Tell Dafana Reconsidered: The Archaeology of an Egyptian Frontier Town (p.44, p.56, p.177, pl.19)
